results.title: Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place
results.credit_line:
Kaylene Whiskey, Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara Lands
Single-channel video, 8 mins
Commissioned by Melbourne Art Foundation in partnership with ACMI
results.brief_description: Yankunytjatjara artist Kaylene Whiskey’s signature pop culture figures fly from the canvas in her latest work, Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place. Whiskey joins them, taking centrestage as a dancing queen with an entourage of seven kungka kunpu (strong women) from her community in Indulkana.
results.description:
“Ngura Pukulpa is all about my Happy Place. My home Indulkana is where I love to be, spending time with all my family and friends, listening to good music and dancing! This video artwork and all my artwork is for everyone to enjoy – I want to share love, happiness, laughter and togetherness with everybody!” – Kaylene Whiskey

Yankunytjatjara artist Kaylene Whiskey’s signature pop-culture figures fly from the canvas in her latest work, Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place. In her paintings, Whiskey introduces iconic figures like Dolly Parton and Whoopi Goldberg to her culture, depicting these heroic women engaging in traditional activities like hunting, collecting bush tucker and cultivating mingkulpa (native tobacco plant). In Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place, Whiskey joins them, taking centrestage as a dancing queen with an entourage of seven kungka kunpu (strong women) from her community in Indulkana. They tear through red-sand roads in a Toyota Land Cruiser, dodging a cake-stealing Santa while an animated Blak Wonder Woman – rendered in her lively, singular style – flies through the live-action dreamscape.

Responding to the Melbourne Art Fair’s 2022 theme of ‘Djeembana / Place’, Whiskey has created a jubilant and irreverent celebration of her community, envisioning a space where imagination mixes with reality, and pop culture collides with traditional Anangu culture. The audience is invited to Indulkana, envisioned as a place of friendship and fantasy, where the joy of connection and Country is expressed through the power of superheroes, Sister Act and song.
description_for_label:
Yankunytjatjara artist Kaylene Whiskey envisions a world where pop culture collides with traditional Anangu culture.

Commissioned by Melbourne Art Foundation in partnership with ACMI, “Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place”, evolves Whiskey’s practice by bringing her dazzling artistry and celebration of sisterhood to the screen. At its centre is Whiskey, a dancing queen with an entourage of seven kungka kunpu (strong women) from her community in Indulkana, who act as back-up for a superstar tearing through red-sand roads in a Toyota Land Cruiser. Along for the party are actual superheroes and superstars – Wonder Woman and Tina Turner materialise in Whiskey’s live-action dreamscape, appearing via vivid animation rendered in her lively, singular style.

[Sourced from ACMI website 3/2/22]

Kaylene Whiskey, Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara Lands

results.title: College Slam for Game Boy
results.creator_credit: Acclaim Entertainment Ltd and Torus Games
results.brief_description:
Part of the NBA Jam series of basketball games, College Slam allows the player to choose from 44 real college teams and take part in head-to-head games, tournaments, and season-long series in arcade-style two-on-two frenetic gameplay. Each side starts out by picking any two out of five players from a team to play with. During timeouts and half-time, the player has a choice to make substitutions. Making three baskets in a row without the other team scoring, powers the player up which makes it easier to score.

This points to the unrealistic nature of the game, where players can make full-court shots with relative ease, characters frequently jump higher than the net and may get struck by lightning during dunks. The game features customizable teams and players and fight songs from all the available teams.

results.title: Dark Reign: The Future of War for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, product registration card, adverts, internet guide sheet and keyboard reference in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
In the grim future of Dark Reign: The Future of War, the player is caught between two factions at war, the Imperium and the Freedom Guard. The player has a chance to go back in time using a time-travelling device and change history but must first complete a set of trails to activate it. Each of these scenarios has the player recreating past battles between the Imperium and Freedom Guard to prove to hone their martial skills.

Each faction has its own unique units, skills and weaknesses. The Freedom Guard are weaker but more mobile, allowing them to better to be faster and handle difficult terrain. The Imperium, in contrast, have the strength and numbers to overwhelm their enemies but are generally slower. These traits lend themselves to radically different playstyles. A player can also steal the other faction’s technology using a specialized unit, negating their opponent’s advantages. The game features a campaign and map editor and supports online play. In fact, there is still an active community despite the game being over 20 years old.

results.title: Warlords for PC
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Three 5 1/4 inch floppy disks, colour map, subscription card, IBM Supplement sheet, Version 2.0 Improvements Sheets and Appendix Sheets in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords is set in the midst of the battle to control the Kingdom of Illuria. The player is put in control one of eight budding empires: The Sirians, Storm Giants, Grey Dwarves, Orcs of Kor, Elvallie, Horse Lords, Selentines, or Lord Bane. Each group has their strengths and weaknesses. The other clans are either controlled by the computer or by another player via hot seat play. The game proceeds on a turn-by-turn basis, with each player issuing commands such as to move units, attack the opposition, order cities to accrue gold, build more units or instruct their heroes to explore Illuria and complete quests before passing the turn to the next player. The game is won once a player has conquered at least half of the kingdom’s eighty cities.

results.title: MTV's Beavis and Butt-head for Game Boy
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge case and  consumer information booklet in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Based on the animated TV series of the same name, the player controls either Beavis or Butt-Head in their quest to escape school and join a gang. Each level’s basic goal is to find the exit without dying, while fetching items or completing objectives along the way. Neither protagonist has a weapon but can find items like tomatoes and spit balls in the environment to use. Powerups can also give the player extra lives or invincibility. The game’s perspective can shift from top-down to side scrolling depending on the level.

results.title: NBA Showtime: NBA on NBC for Game Boy Color
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, manual, registration card, consumer information booklet and Nintendo Power advert in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
A 2D adaptation of the 3D console game, this port maintains the fast, action-packed and unrealistic two on two style of basketball from the original. The switch to 2D actually harkens back to the series’ roots, which began in the same style before switching to 3D.

The game includes all 29 teams of the 1999-2000 NBA season, with over 100 featured players. Modes include exhibition games, full season, playoffs and a practice mode.

results.title: Aussie Rules Footy for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.

results.title: Warlords II Scenario Builder for DOS
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Three 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, CD-ROM, CD jewel case, registration card, subscription card, catalogue and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords II: Scenario Builder allows for an improved amount of customization to the base Warlords II game. These include the ability to edit the map, add new items, write descriptive text, create new unit and city graphics using a pixel editor and even change specific unit characteristics. 24 new scenarios also come with the pack, including ones that draw from historic sources like Medieval England to more far-fetched situations, like an alien invasion.
results.description: Warlords II: Scenario Builder allows for an improved amount of customization to the base Warlords II game. These include the ability to edit the map, add new items, write descriptive text, create new unit and city graphics using a pixel editor and even change specific unit characteristics. 24 new scenarios also come with the pack, including ones that draw from historic sources like Medieval England to more far-fetched situations, like an alien invasion.
description_for_label: Warlords II: Scenario Builder allows for an improved amount of customization to the base Warlords II game. These include the ability to edit the map, add new items, write descriptive text, create new unit and city graphics using a pixel editor and even change specific unit characteristics. 24 new scenarios also come with the pack, including ones that draw from historic sources like Medieval England to more far-fetched situations, like an alien invasion.
